print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Wanhao i3/Monoprice Maker Select V2 Y Motor Mount Spacer Plate

description.text:
I was tired of the flex generated on the thin metal Y axis motor mount when belt tension was applied.

The rear Y axis motor mount bends and this spacer/plate stops the motor from bending inward when tension is made to the shaft.

Probably the simplest mod around, best bang for the filament, saves wear on bed bearings as well. Requires no new hardware - just bolt it on for better print results.

Remove the mount, remove the motor, place spacer plate in place, attach the motor to the mount, attach the mount to the frame.

This was made for the Monoprice Maker Select V2, which should work with any of the Wanhao Variants.

**Added additional file for people with the 40mm width motor, the original one is for the 34mm width motor - Enjoy!

Wanhao

comments.text: How do I ensure the timing belt has the "appropriate" amount of tension?  I have a project to expand the bed from 200x200 to 200x300 and I'm sure of most of it except for having to create a new timing belt.   I was going to insert these at the same time.
comments.author: famewolf

comments.text: Nice job here. Why didn't I think of this? All this time I've been using a longer M3 screw to push the Y-motor into alignment. After that I doubled the belt tension and the whole metal frame started to bend. So then I used some plywood we had sitting around to brace the Y-axis. With tension doubled, the accuracy is much improved at higher print speeds.

description.text:
This is my litho pane light box for 3D Printed litho panes. I created this so I could more easily show off and gift a few lithos I had printed. I use this light box in conjunction with the frame customizer from Thingiverse which is linked below.
The light box is approx 90mmX115MM. I insert a hole in the back of whatever frame I am using at 90.5x115.5mm and about 2-3MM deep. This is the channel that I glue the light box to the frame via with super glue. Before I glue my light box to the back of my frame, I apply aluminum foil tape to the inside of the box. This helps the little tea lights reflect more light against the litho picture.

I use battery powered LED tea lights to light these up. You can fit 2 of them in my box at the desgned scale.

This is the frame customizer I use from Thingiverse
http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=54020&code=9b40f444938a2a525affe3a96df5e34a

I print this in PLA. Supports not required. I run infill on this around 10%.

print_settings.Notes:: Print vertically

description.text:
Really simple 'gaff ramp'. I am a sound technician and have to run audio and power cables. Usually, these cables get taped to the floor using gaffer tape. However, that often leaves tape residue on the cables, especially long term.

This is my solution to avoiding gaff residue on cables. It fits a fair amount of cables in it, and can be scaled for most applications. I am still testing these, but the idea is to use them in low traffic areas about every 3 feet. I place the cover over the cables and tape down. When I'm finished, simply pull the tape off, and your cables are ready to be put away (no tape residue!).

Let me know if you make one or use it. Its a super simple design, but I think it will save me messy cable to deal with.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.5

Infill:

25

Notes:

Print vertically

The design is based off of the traditional cable ramps, which cover the entire cable. This device is much smaller and only covers parts of the cable.

The purpose was to print a device to secure cables to the ground without them coming in direct contact with an adhesive.

Requirements are to limit material used, minimize profile, and withstand approximately 200 lbs of weight (i.e. a person or most road cases).

comments.text: Hi Shawny. I hope you find it useful. I Designed it to use in my woodworking. I'm a professional woodworker in Australia. You'll see the sort of work I do on my website designsinwood.com.au I dabbled in 3d printing some years ago, which is when I designed the Bench Cookie. I had purchased a 3d printer in kit form from India on Ebay. I had many issues with it, and was unable to get into the firmware to calibrate it. After many months of searching on line, I came across a Frenchman on a forum who had the same printer, and had experienced the same calibration issue. He had discovered a way to replace the firmware which enabled the printer to be calibrated. I followed his method and was able to install Repetier on the board, and calibrate the printer. I then had problems with the extruder! I have replaced the extruder since, but haven't bothered to continue playing with the 3d printer. I am quite a technical person, but I discovered that 3d printing is a very immature field, and that it is frustrating if you are trying to achieve quality results! You may be interested in looking at a video on my YouTube channel. There are only two videos on it. I've been a bit slack in producing more videos. The link I'll add here shows the operation of a CNC Mill I designed and made, and which I use in my woodworking. I trust you will find it interesting. Here is the link. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5VpEDf2GkNY Regards, Denis.
comments.author: sinbad

comments.text: very cool, printing now!

remixed_from.title: Foldable drone frame (wider body, higher ground clearence,bottom access plate) Remix

title: Mavic by mwilmar front arms w/ less supports

description.text:
These are the remixed front arms that now lay flat on the build plate with less supports and faster print. I removed the short pivot pins and replaced them with a through hole on the arm. The pins are now separate. There are two pins, one with a slot for wires and one without. You can use either.

There is also two different arms. One are is labeled "nowasher". The other set of arms is labeled "washer". The "nowasher" file still has the raised area on the bottom, around the pivot pin as the original does.The "nowasher" file will still have a step in the support which could cause irregularities in that area.
The file labeled "washer" has the lower raised area removed for a easier flat print. If you use the "washer" file, you may need a shim such as a thin phenolic washer to take up the small gap between the arm and main body. This would also reduce wear. The "washer" file will print flat on the pivot area support.

I have not printed this yet. I will print and test fit in the next day or so and report back. I will also upload photos further explaining the "washer" vs. "nowasher" arms.

UPDATE 11/01/2017: The "washer" arms fit great!!(WITHOUT the added washer!) The pin is about +/-1mm too tall. I just sanded it down until it fit good when the head bottom is tightned down to the main body. This may differ from print to print as the part were the pin goes into the main body is printed on a support so fluctuations in that layer is possible depending on the support infill you use on the main body. I will upload photos soon.

I have not printed the "nowasher" version as I am pleased with the "washer" version WITHOUT the washer added.

I also added the landing leg "glue piece" file.

Remove supports and debur pin and pin hole if needed.

UPDATE 11/01/2017: Shorten pins +/-1mm with sanding or filing.

author: t2krookie

remixed_from.author: SexyCyborg
remixed_from.title: Thieves' Purse- a game for building spatial visualization and Chinese reading skills.

title: Zhuyin's Treasure Hunt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I've currently been studying Mandarin Chinese for a little over a year and when I came across @SexyCyborg 's design "Thieves' Purse- a game for building spatial visualization and Chinese reading skills" I was inspired. Her idea and concept is a really well thought one and I wanted to build upon it in this design. I like the idea of using a game as a means of being able to teach children/players to develop spatial skills by using touch. I believe being hands on this way is really beneficial to the learners because it uses the brain in multiple ways to develop intuitive and reinforced solutions to problem solving. To quote SexyCyborg directly "it requires the player have a strong mental image, and be able to rotate that image in their mind." I cannot agree more because having this ability will be a solid foundation for Chinese language learners and for building spatial intelligence. However, In this approach I decided to take a step back from 'Chinese character reading' and focus more on 'Chinese pronunciation.' One reason for doing this is because of the shear number of Chinese characters. From what I've read there are thousands upon thousands of characters, some say 10,000+. Therefore, to try to continually update your coins to learn new characters didn't quite seem efficient to me.

Luckily, for us, there is a romanized phonetic system called pinyin which helps with the phonetic pronunciation of the Chinese words and Characters. This method is very effective for teaching beginners how to speak properly. It is also useful when translating and texting as most Chinese characters can be selected from a secondary menu when someone writes in pinyin. This takes away the burden of having to write every character in a small drawing space where your keyboard would normally be located. Likewise, there is a less known phonetic system called Zhuyin(bopomofo). This system is primarily used in Taiwan and is taught in kindergarden and first grade. The Taiwanese school system uses Zhuyin to lay a solid foundation for Chinese pronunciation, and stroke order, and then in first or second grade begins teaching Traditional Character writing. Unlike the ten thousands of Chinese characters, Zhuyin uses only 37 characters and 4 tones. This is a number that I can manage to design and easily remember. All while providing the same game challenges set forth in SexyCyborgs original game concept. Similarly, Zhuyin(Bopomofo) can also be useful when texting and translating as it also has its own keyboard, but unlike pinyin, learning Zhuyin gives you the beginnings of one of the most crucial concepts of learning Chinese Characters; stroke order.

With that being said, I've made these 37 characters and 4 tones available to you using @SexyCyborgs design as a medium. I want to keep the same ideas of choosing coins blindly, and guessing the coins character based on the way they feel. However, I want to add the challenge of creating words with the Zhuyin and use those words in a point system of sorts. This may require you to print out two sets of coins, but hey the children will love it.

Looking forward, I generally see this being used in an education setting by teachers and tutors and I think the appeal of "treasure" will incaptivate children. However, I do not think the 'well written' story of "Bàn Jī and the Thieves' Purse", which may encourage children to steal, will go over too well with teachers or parents. That being said I've decided to call this version "Zhuyin's Treasure Hunt". I challenge you all to help make a story and rules set based off of @SexyCyborg 's "Bàn Jī and the Thieves' Purse" located at
http://sexycyborg.net/Ban_Ji_and_the_Thieves_Purse.html
This project will be updated in the future as a story develops and rules are formally set.
If you've made it this far thank you for reading my word wall.
If you like my work and designs you can also find me (@midheaventech) on
•Twitter•
•Tumblr•
•Thingiverse•
•Instructables•
•Etsy•
•3DHubs•
•Patreon•
I'm just getting started, so if places seem kinda bare here and there, thank you for understanding. If anyone has any tips and tricks, I'm open to all feedback . Thankss

Don't forget to check out the original design and like/follow @SexyCyborg.

P.S. Here is a wiki page about Zhuyin this will further explain how to use it and the sounds each character makes.

remixed_from.author: DesignMakeTeach
remixed_from.title: MLK March on Washington Button & Lesson Plan

description.text:
This Birmingham Jail Key replica is intended to serve as a classroom manipulative for Martin Luther King Jr. Day and Black History Month. The artifact asks students to think about the long struggle and sacrifices of the people involved in the Civil Right Movement.

One lesson idea would be to use the key as a Mystery Artifact where students take on the role of historical experts and have to research and present the significance and historical value of the object. Students would need to discover the connection between the key and Martin Luther King Jr. and then the significance of the Letter from Birmingham Jail. See Antiques Roadshow, American Pickers or Pawn Stars as possible templates for the class presentations. Further discussion might lead to the topic of nonviolent civil disobedience.

What is this object?
What does it do?
What is its historical significance?

The key is an example of the type of artifacts that students might produce for Design Challenge - MLK 2017 https://designmaketeach.com/2017/01/05/design-challenge-mlk-2017/

See also MLK March on Washington Button & Lesson Plan http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2018467

For photo of a Birmingham Jail Key from 1963 or info about Martin Luther King Jr.'s Letter from Birmingham Jail, visit the following links.
http://szmarkman.zenfolio.com/natgeo_aia_exhibit/h3A176F7E#h3a176f7e
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter_from_Birmingham_Jail

If you or your students would like to help improve the text description for this piece or contribute a more accurate model, please leave a comment or contact me on Twitter @DesignMakeTeach

title: OO/HO TRACK PENCIL HOLDER MKII
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I could not help myself when I made the previous version I was thinking of doing this, but took the easy way out, and because of the interest in the MKI http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2025266, here is the MKII.

The number of times I have had to trace along a piece of track to mark out where I want to lay the underlay, or marking out the curved form-work to lay the track.

Of course one does not have a set of radius curves of every size so this simple device joined up with the OO/HO FLEXITRACK CURVE FORMING CLAMPS in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2023001 you can make a radius template any size you like, and is not limited to model railways uses either.

The pencil needs to slide easily in the holder and may need a bit of extra weight added.
Wheels are on a 2mm axle, but may need changing to suit what you have lying around

wheel slots

The axle slots are set at 2mm but will print tight so I used a 2.5mm drill run through the bottom of the slot so the axle needs to be pushed past the narrow bit and will snap into place.
The bogie is 13mm wide so may need to be adjusted to suit your axles.

author: timbologist

description.text: This is basically the same as the original, except I added a bump on the inside where the air escapes. This difference focuses the air flow, creating the whistle noise. When I printed the original, I couldn't get the noise, but with this extra bump, I am getting a whistling. I might experiment with different size bumps.

title: Rotocaster / Rotomolder  made from common parts

description.text:
THIS IS STILL A WORK IN PROGRESS!
Main frame components are solid and work well, bearing and bolt mounts too. The feet need to be modified to include more bracing and pulleys/motor are still being fiddled with(NEMA17 works great but it's the most complicated).
instructions are still being worked on and model files may be reorganized or changed.

That being said. The machine works well and has made an number of urethane, silicon and chocolate casts of different types. I'll include some photos later.
Photos now include all the needed detail, so you should be able to build one from that and help me find any missed mistakes!
If you have any problems, I'll try and respond to comments and fix minor problems.

PLEASE MODIFY THIS DESIGN
This was made partly as I wanted something that was easy to make, was flexible in size, didn't use gears and was cheap. My build costs are about AU$35 not including motor.
I'd love for someone to redo this, a lot more care could be taken to reduce the amount of filament required, especially on the corners. The current design was made to be simple and solid.
The aluminium size is common in Australia and I suspect other metric places in the world, however a version may be needed using whatever the nearest imperial size is.
An improved version could also reduce the number of bearings to 6 by replacing the single large aluminium with two smaller ones, one either side of a single bearing. Like a 'H'.

Hardware BOM
3m of 10x20x3mm aluminium. (Lager one was made from 10x20mm bar stock. Heavy!)
Cut list small(150x250): 2x 150mm, 2x 200mm, 6x 250mm, 2x 300mm.
Cut list big size(250x250): (keep forgetting)
10x 608 bearings
6x M8 Bolt 65mm
1x M8 Bolt 75mm
14x M8 Nut
4x M8 Nylock (Optional, better machine but harder to work on)
6x M8 Washer
Rubber bands (No.34 100x3mm worked for me)
Optional: GT2 2x6mm belt + neoprene glue. Or GT2 continuous belt large enough and some way to tension it. (You can use rubber bands instead, but the machine has some strange wobbles and effects. OK for a test, but I'd not recommend it.)
Recommended joiner for GT2 belt: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1814419

Tools
Metal cutting saw. (Hacksaw works)
8mm drill bit
3mm drill bit
Countersink bit or taperd reamer
Basic hand tools, including ruler.

Print list
Due to the number of parts involved, they have been organised into 'plates' to suit a 100mm square print bed(Such as the Up! Mini's) so should work on most printers. Most slices can break these up if you want to fit more on larger build plates.
The machine pictured was printed in cheap Red ABS on an modified Prusa i3 clone. 2 shells top/bottom and 2 on sides with typically 20% infill.

2x Corners
1x either Smooth OR GT2 pulley set
1x everything else
1x motor(optional)

Optional
I will not offer help for this side of things. DC motor is cheap/easy to drive, but runs a bit fast and has low torque.

  • https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20170210075356&SearchText=Right-angle+Gear+Motor+car
  • NEMA 17 is strong, controllable but takes more effort. I used an broken GRBL board.
    Or NEMA 17 stepper + electronics

Test video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QeE7XG8RrDU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YhfUAERnrJA

Instructions are going to be fairly minimal and include only critical steps.
Photos should include enough to build it. More photos should be added over the next few weeks.

Cut all aluminium to length. I used to a wood drop/miter saw but it works just as well, if slower, using a hacksaw. Exact lengths are not super critical, however each pair of lengths should be the same or you'll get excess wobble. Clean up the ends.
Put aside the two pieces of the base and two for the sides.
In all other pieces find the center and mark. Put a bearing in one of the 3d printed side(From 'Leftovers' plate), slid onto aluminum until the bearing hole is centered with the mark and drill 8mm holes using bearing as a guide. You could also use 8mm bit just to mark the center, pilot with 3mm bit then drill through with 8mm.

  • Deburr each hole. On the holes that will be against bearings, use the countersink bit to shape the hole to allow clearance for the bearing center to turn. This requires quite a deep countersink. See photos.
    Vertical leg pieces are the same, except the bearing end is aligned with the end rather than center of the aluminium tube. See photos.
    Assemble. The 75mm bolt goes through the handle side. Tape works well to hold the frame together. Once it's aligned, use the 3mm bit to into the aluminium through the locking/securing holes. Using screws of the right size, secure together. Long bolts should also work.
    *Use washers as spacers to ensure there is no slop when assembling. 2 washers at the top and 2 at the bottom between the bearings and nut holder were used.
  • If you get to this step I should have more photos/instructions showing the rest.

MORE NOTES:

  • Any place that a pulley attaches to a bolt, screw on a nylock first and drop the pulley over that. It'll stop it from moving when in use. A normal nut then retains it.
  • You may need extra long screws to attach the side/center pulley to the leg piece. I just drilled right through and put a 4mm bolt in place.
  • Top belt guides have 2 washers each between the corner and bearing center if you have the guides with pulley insert side inwards. If they are loose, clean out the retaining lip with a knife and a few wraps of tape stop them from twisting and dropping the belt.
  • Once pulleys/guides are in place, THEN add counterweight nuts to the other corners. Make sure the machine can spin freely and has little bias.
    Wrap a GT2 belt around them and measure for final size. If you do it with teeth up on the guide wheels, turning the belt over later to ride on the teeth gives a little extra tension if needed, but even slightly loose belts work well.

description.text:
This is a speaker wall mount I designed to hang my rear surround speakers up near the ceiling. My speakers are Monoprice brand and the back faces measure 100mm wide by 160mm tall. Depth wasn't pertinent so I don't remember it. The angle of the bracket was just right so that the bottom the speaker came 5mm from the wall. The center hole is sized for the machine screw that fit my speakers: 1/4" diameter. I think this is a standard size for speakers but I'm not sure.

Including the design I did in Sketchup since I assume it'll need to be modified for a speaker of any other size.

If you want to make your own versions you might think about a better way to screw in the machine screw. The install instructions are to put the machine screw in the bracket, screw the bracket into a stud, plug the wires into your speaker, then put your speaker on the screw and try to turn it with a wrench from behind the speaker. The last step is awkward and you can't see what you're doing. I ended up printing a flat wrench for the job.

This is meant to be a visual aid in teaching the "shell method" of solids of rotation, a unit frequently taught in Calculus 1 classes.

Model measures 170mm square at the base and 130mm tall
NGSS

Each concentric shell width is 'dx' As displayed on the model, the equation shown is y=-x^2+a (some arbitrary constant). A student may be asked a question like "What is the volume of the figure created when y=-x^2+9 is revolved around the y axis?" Knowing that each 'slice' of width dx and height y gives a cross-sectional area that can then be multiplied by 2pi × x (the average radius of slice) to get the volume of that individual shell, the student can use integration to find the entire volume of the rotational solid: 2pi × the integral of yxdx = 2pi × int((-x^2+9)(x)dx = int((-x^3+9x)dx) = -x^4/4 + 9/2x^2
evaluated from x = 0 to x = 3: 2pi × (-20.25 + 40.5) = 2pi × 20.25
= 40.5pi

1) Review conceptual understanding of integrating with respect to x: the area under the curve is broken up into very thin, rectangular slices of width 'dx'. The area of each of these rectangles is height × width, where the height is the value of the function at x' and the width is dx. Therefore, A=y(x')dx
2) Remind students of geometric formula for finding the volume of a solid cylinder, V=pi×r^2×h. Lead the students to realize that to find the volume of a hollow cylinder or "shell" the formula can be modified to be V=2pi×(r1^2-r2^2)×h.
3) Illustrate a function being revolved around the y axis, restate the thin rectangular slices and lead students to draw similarities between these slices, the revolution, and the cylindrical shell equation.
4) Piece by piece, show that 2pi is a constant and can be left alone, r1^2-r2^2 = xdx, and h = y(x'). That addresses a single shell, but they know how to integrate to add up all the dx's. This leaves you with V = 2pi × int(yxdx) from x=0 to whatever upper bound is appropriate for the problem.
5) Pass around the model and allow students to stack and unstack, revolve, and understand how the 2 dimensional function translates to a revolved solid that can be broken up into concentric shells.

title: IKEA Lack Table Enclosure filament pass-thru

description.text:
This is a twist-lock porthole/filament guide for use with IKEA Lack table enclosures. The Lack table top is 50mm thick so the original Thing wouldn't work for it.

Drill a 38mm (or 1.5 inch) hole into the top of your Lack table, insert the main flange, insert the nozzle from the bottom, then twist the cap on. The cap will hold the nozzle in place and there is a lip in the main flange to keep it from moving up.

The nozzle has a 4.3mm hole which (when printed on my machine) just barely fit a 4mm PTFE bowden tube. You may need to drill the hole larger to suit your purpose. If the swivel doesn't move smoothly, chuck the small tip up in a drill, hold on to the collar and spin away. This will knock down any high spots. Added some Super Lube for good measure.

author: g3org

title: Airsoft P90 BTC Chimera/HPA trigger and selector microswitch conversion

description.text:
This is the 3D printed hardware you could use to convert a Tokyo Marui P90 from the standard trigger and selector mechanism, to micro switches for both jobs. This is intended to be used with either a BTC Chimera, a HPA system such as a Polarstar, or your own home brew setup.

In some of the supplied pictures I used a switch I had lying around as an example. The first photo and the photo of the small tactile switch, show the correct switch, which is a SP0603 6mm SPST Micro Tactile switch from Jaycar Electronics. You should be able to find something similar nearly anywhere. https://www.jaycar.co.nz/6mm-spst-micro-tactile-switch/p/SP0603

The microswitch for the selector is also from Jaycar, and is an SM1036, also a very common design. One of the STL files models the body of this switch so you can compare. You do not have to print that part. https://www.jaycar.co.nz/spdt-sub-miniature-microswitch/p/SM1036

Trickiest part of the install is gluing the two selector mounts up inside the body. It is actually quite easy with a pair of angled tweezers and some super glue. Just hold each mount as far back and up as it will go. I haven't tried acetone to see if that will work, as I wanted to be able to remove it during development.

Cut some rectangles out of 1.2mm thick prototyping board to suit. The selector one has a rectangle cut into that to allow the bottom of the switch to sit flush with the bottom of the board. It cannot sit lower, as correctly installed the selector board mounts sit the board as low as possible.

The selector switch requires a small lump to be added to push on the micro switch, as per the photo. You can use whatever, I used some epoxy putty.

The trigger stop and trigger button depressor have a little extra meat on them. Sand these to suit. There should be no excess travel on the trigger microswitch, or during a game under stress you will definitely over squeeze it and break the glue on your mount or damage the switch itself.

I figure if you are actually undertaking such a conversion, a little gluing/soldering/sanding the trigger tolerance is probably no challenge to you.

This was all done in Sketchup, and printed on a completely stock DaVinci.

remixed_from.author: _ZincBoy_
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator 6 blower fan upgrade for extruder and part cooling

title: Zortrax M200 radial fan shroud for extruder heatsink

description.text:
After some tests with the beautiful D6 blower fan upgrade by ZincBoy (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1666096) on my Zortrax M200, I decided to remix his design to better fit my printer.
I think ZincBoy has tilted the fan for some reason, perhaps to improve the airflow. But after a test with the blower positioned parallel to the heat sink I did not detect evaluable differences. I don't own the D6, but the original shroud doesn't fully exploit the cooling fins, then I increased the lower opening to expand the area hit by the air flow.

The radial fan to be used is the BFB0412HHA-A that you can order from digikey, mouser etc.
The fan is locked in place with #3 wood screws.
You need also a 12V regulator because the M200 send a voltage spike which destroys the fan during startup and also because the operating voltage is beyond the specification of the BFB0412HHA-A.
I've opted for the Pololu D24V5F12 (https://www.pololu.com/product/2846), a 12V/500mA switching step-down well-known by the fpv racing drones users. It is located between the shroud and the fan, in a dedicated housing. Its wiring should not be a problem.
Even with the step-down, the fan power supply isn't linear stabilized, you need a capacitor on the step-down input to have steady 12V. See below for wiring.

Printer Brand:

Zortrax

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.19 - 0.14

Infill:

high

Notes:

Print as in the stl position, with Z-ABS, smart bridges enabled and 100% fan.

Comparison between the stock axial fan and the BFB0412HHA-A Stock fan Stock fan Centrifugal fan with shroud Centrifugal fan with shroud Capacitor wiring

If you put a tiny 22uF/50V capacitor in parallel to the JST plug, the radial fan works at 12V cc, without the capacitor, something less. Here some shots of capacitor wiring.

Kapton tape Pay attention on the capacitor polarity. Important: close it all with a heat shrinkable tube. Step-down wiring.

comments.text: So you remixed the heat sink cooler and it looks awesome, but why didn't you add "zincboys" part cooling fan as well?
comments.author: Nytroxxx

comments.text: Do you mean the anular extruder shroud? I must first have to find a reliable way to use the centrifugal fan so as to vary the rpms without the 30 volt peak to peak destroy it.
comments.author: Nytroxxx

comments.text: Yes the annular part cooling fan and shroud. Won't the same 12v regulator used in this design control the spike in voltage? and doesn't the Zortrax control the existing stock fans RPM already or is it a full on or off fan control?
comments.author: liftbag

comments.text:
The point is that the M200 controls only the extruder fan RPMs, but not in the way you think, not with a variable tension, but with a PWM control. If I put a step-down regulator I prevent almost completely the RPM adjustment, with the fan that works almost every time at maximum speed.
I might opt for a traditional axial fan, but it is proven that they are not adapted to work with shrouds. They are designed to implement a air change in cabinets and lose much of their efficiency as soon as the air ejection area approaches an obstacle. They exert very little pressure.
That's why the centrifugal blowers would be the way to go with radiator shrouds that shrink. Unfortunately, this particular type of centrifugal fan does not survive the M200 PWM control.
comments.author: Nytroxxx

comments.text: I don't know if the M200 electronics are the same as the Wanhao version.  On the Wanhao version, the PWM is on the low side (switched ground).  +24V is constant on the hot end and is used to supply the heater and both fans. The ground for all three is switched.  To regulate down the +24V you need to run a ground wire to the head along the ribbon cable and use that for the negative supply on the regulator.  The positive of the fan is connected to the regulator output.  The fan negative is connected to the negative on the breakout board on the head.
comments.author: liftbag

comments.text: Hi ZincBoy. On the M200 the ground is common. I have to edit the thing summary, because I wrote it before checking with the oscilloscope that the fans are controlled by a PWM. In any case, it's the +24V transient which destroys the electronics of the radial fan.

author: ealltech

title: Magnetic tray for a 30x10mm NIB magnet

description.text:
This is a magnetic tray for a mini monster cylindrical 30mm diam x10mm height NIB magnet, The design is thought to be printed in semiflex material (at least the base), as it is intended to be assembled press fitting the two parts holding inside the magnet. You will need strong hands to assemble this. Thing dimensions are 60mm diam. x 26mm height.

Warning, be careful handling this kind of super magnets as you can easily smash your fingers. This tray holds inside the magnet not only to protect it from scratches, but also to protect your fingers and avoid direct contact with the magnet to metalic surfaces (where removal of the magnet could be tricky). Remember this magnets are not toys. Remember also that if it grabs some ferromagnetic screw, it will hold it STEADY. If you have ferromagnetic pearcings keep away from this heheh.

An adapter for a softer 20mmx10mm magnet is also supplied. You can make your own just in case, or simply use some resin to keep your own magnet in place, there's plenty room for it ;-)

At printing time, base part doesn't require support, but tray part does require baseplate support. I felt very easy to remove elastic support from my semiflex printed trays. Do NOT print BOTH PARTS in a non elastic material as you won't be able to assemble it. I printed the trays shown in the pictures as this: bases in ABS and the top parts in semiflex material. But I recommend to print in semiflex the base part as it would be more elastic due to its smaller height and this will ease the assembling of the whole thing. If you have strong hands forget the latter.

This is the big brother of my other design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2012292

Enjoy.

author: Despild

title: Graperain ARM system on module
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
System on Module is the MINI PC's core functions packaged in an electronic board packaging. Most of the system-on-module integrates the CPU, memory devices and pins, through the pin and supporting the bottom plate connected together to achieve a field of system chips. People often such a system called the microcontroller, or an embedded development platform. Because the system-on-module integrates the core of the common functions, so it has a c system-on-module can customize the versatility of the different floor, which greatly improves the development efficiency of the microcontroller. Because the system-on-module as a separate module separated, it also reduces the development of the difficulty, an increase of system stability and maintainability.

G3288 development board supports gigabit Ethernet, audio, wifi, BT, gyroscope, camera, etc. onboard HDMI, LVDS ports, MIPI and USB ports,etc. Meanwhile the hardware keep its uniform style, supports software power on/off, dormancy awakening and so on.

description.text:
This is a 3-piece rim that I designed for my 1:10 MB jeep project, I decided to upload it separately since it can be used on any crawler.

The tyres in the photo are these, but the rims should work with any 1.9 tyres.

Tips are always appreciated and go straight back into buying parts to fund new projects, all of which get released for free.

Hardware Required
(5) M2x10mm screws
(5) M2 nuts

The nuts should fit in just right, but if the holes are too tight then just press them in with a hot soldering iron (or use a longer bolt to pull them into place, then replace with a shorter bolt).

author: sasi

title: DJI Phantom 3 motor protection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I recently bought a DJI Phantom 3 Standard. With that, I also bought a nice backpack in which to store and transport my drone.
As you can see in the pictures, the drone is stored (or at least when putting it in the backpack) upside down.
I therefor wanted to have something to protect the motors so that the weight of the drone would not rest on top of the motors but rather on the frame.
I looked around on thingiverse (and 'the rest of the internet'), but could not find one that suited my needs. I therefor decided to create my own.

I created this in OpenSCAD and used the 'QUICK RELEASE propeller guard (Phantom 1/2/3) by Meissler (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1324097) as a reference for the motor protection to snap on to the drone.
In this way, the motor protection easily snaps on and snaps off when needed (but not while in transport). I wanted this, because I do not want to spend long minutes in the field preparing the drone for a flight (starting up the DJI app and calibrating the compass already takes some time).

The original of Meissler also had some knobs which slotted nicely into place on the underside of the drone, but I found I do not need them (they even hinder me to quickly snap on and snap off the motor protection). In the OpenSCAD file you can enable these knobs if you feel you need them (just set the 'ShowKnobs' variable to true).

Many thanks to Meissler for the example. I learned a lot reverse engineering his design.

Enjoy and let me know (and see) when you print this.

Note: I don't think it is important, but I used the 2016 version of OpenScad (I think the official 2015 version should work just fine).

Printer:

Hesine

Rafts:

No

Yes

Resolution:

.4 nozzle, .2 layers

20%

description.text:
Throwing a row of dominoes is fun, but placing them is boring. This tool can place 8 dominoes in a row. By combining more of them (super glue), longer tools are possible. However, a short tool gives more flexibility when making curves. The placement procedure is repeated until the row is long enough. The tool has slots for two different domino sizes. The scad file is included, so other geometries (thickness, distance between dominoes) can be realized.

author: Astrofossil

description.text:
Here i come with my last modification of 3Dator Bowden Extruder.
Derivated from my last version (i2)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1679553

!!!ALL MY MOUNTS FOR EVERY VERSION OF EXTRUDER IS HERE!!!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2027391

Developed for high-speed prints, because i have broken few little fittings when trying to print fast with 0,3mm nozzle.there is too much pressure for M5/M6 fitting.M10 or R1/8 fitting seems to be far stronger.I have success with mounting that big fitting inside, but only with custom made nut (16x13x4mm).DIN557 nuts are too big.so if you want this version, you have to make that custom nut.

Changes:
-fitting mount redesigned again, for M10 or R1/8 fitting
-both of them can be mounted in M10 nut
-new flexible holder, reducing noise and vibrations
-holder and tightener are back compatible for all versions of extruder
-2 variations of the base plate, depending on mode of bowden tube installation:
variant with additional hole inside is for mounting the tube through the fitting (need lathe for fitting modification).this way, end of tube is inside the baseplate.not inside the fitting, as can you see on image.

This is propably my last remix of that extruder.i thing theres no options for next evolution.i am happy with it now.
I am working on my own extruder, with double MK8 gear (both driven) for ultimate grip and 1:3 gearbox.

Printer:

monstrous steel beast without name :D

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,15

Infill:

30

Notes:

Use support for tightener only.
Use ABS for extruder and PET(G) for holder.honeycomb infill recomended.
Print Baseplate with 0,1 - 0,15mm layer

title: SUP - fin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to take my 9'' fanatic fly air SUP (http://www.fanatic.com/product/fly-air-2/) out on the lake, but the fin setup that comes with it out of the package is made for wave-riding.....so i decided to print a bigger fin to be able to paddle a little bit straighter ;)

The fin is printed out of 6 individual parts (due to the maximum boundary of the Makerbot Replicator 2) whereas 3 make one side. the 2 grid part click on the respective base part to guarantee a more rigid connection.
Then glued together (I added a coloured sheet of plastic-foil in between for a nice effect) and covered in three layers of fiberglass-fabric and epoxy-glue.....and then hand-sanded forever :) and finished with some clear-spray-paint.

As the front guiding edge of the fin looked a bit messy because of the warping of the 3d-prints I decided to add a layer of red spray-paint on the edge.
I reused the brass pin and pieces to fix it in the fin box from an old broken fin.
The base fits in the the standard "US Box" (the maximum that can fit in ;)
The overall shape of the fin is loosely inspired by one of the future fins (http://www.futuresfins.com.au/sup-1/)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

a heated print-bed would be much much better as the warping distorts the print pieces a lot and a lot of clamps are needed to glue them together and bend them back into their intended shape....

lots of gluing and sanding....

gluing (fiber)glassing sanding

author: iamDarK

print_settings.Printer:: ANET A8 Prusa i3 DIY Kit

title: ANET A8 Power Supply Cover with ISOLATED IEC Socket

description.text:
Browsing for other PSU Covers, none of them had a separation for the IEC socket. The socket I was able to get exposes the mains voltage on its back. So this power cover provides a separate housing for the IEC socket inside the cover itself. Should a low power cable ever become loose it is much less likely to touch mains and therby most likely kill your printer electronics.

All Major variables are editable in the OpenSCAD header section.

Printer:

ANET A8 Prusa i3 DIY Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10% (in fact 100%,due to low wall thickness)

Notes:

Renkforce 1.75mm PLA used.
Slic3r.

Extrude-Temperature: 210°C
Bed-Temperature: 53°C

Connecting

Solder 3 flexible wires to the IEC socket, be sure to make them long enough for some maneuvering, but not too long to avoid fitting problems.

  1. Pull Wires through the hole in the inner socket-housing
  2. Snap the Socket into the front
  3. Connect wires to PSU
  4. (optional) Connect a LedStrip like this one
After Soldering apply some heat shrink on the mains-terminals Pull wires through hole in socket-housing Connect to PSU and optionally wire the any Led-Strip Mounting
  1. Screw Cover in place on the left using a short M3 screw.
  2. Use a zip-tie for the right hand side (my PSU has no screwing option here)
And screw right (Note: My screw is to long, that's why i used a nut) Use Ziptie Left

As asked by @mcorl in the comments, here is a quick guide on how to make the walls thicker. Hint: I printed the object onto painter tape and removed the tape together with the object to avoid rupture.

If you still want to have tougher walls, just increase the "Wall" variable to 2 (line 18) or even bigger if you like. You can also make the front (line 19) thicker but be aware, that this might interfere with your socket/switch-combo. After you changed the values update the preview (F5), if you are happy with the results render the object (F6) and export it with the STL-button.

comments.text: I guess I'll have to take another look wt the program. Thanks for the editing notes.
comments.author: Markcorl

comments.text: I made this. Amazing that I printed it standing up, just like in your picture, and the opening for the switch was prefect, as in no support to remove. Unfortunately, when I tried to remove it from my bed, the internal box ripped upwards, from the center of the hole you can see in the above picture, all the way across the back wall, and all the way forwards to the front of the box. All of the surfaces of this cover are way too thin in my opinion. It's great that it prints in just over three hours, but if the result is visually pleasing, but structurally weak, that's no good. Can you please provide some more information on how to edit the scad file? Thanks.
comments.author: mcorl

comments.text: It prints without support, because I added the 3 beams in the ceiling of the socket, that did the trick (had 2 failed prints before). I printed it on painters tape and removed the finished print from the bed by slowly peeling the tape (with the object still on it). The structure of my object is quite sturdy, but I guess it depends a lot on the filament and other settings.

description.text:
I did not like to use the whole effector+nozzle as a z probe because it was giving me unreliable results due to, I think, too many moving parts and too many possible points of failure.

So I designed a removable Z probe mount to be used with an endstop switch. The mount fits snugly in one of the holes under the effector. The endstop holds best if screwed with M3x10mm bolts. 12mm is too long, unless you use a washer.. but then it gets very close to the heater cables. 8mm might work depending on how well the screw holes are printed..but again - go for 10mm to be safe. I made a lip on the side for easy removal of the mount with a couple of twisting moves.

You will have to adjust the probe X-Y offset and trigger height in the firmware of your choice.

I have successfully used this probe with Marlin firmware and it gave me nice and repeatable results...I just couldn't figure out how to save the settings so I wouldn't need to reprobe again and again. However it seems that doing g28 -> g29 -> m500 should've worked.

If you're coming from stock Micromake D1 settings, you'll need to invert z_min endstop.

Printer:

Micromake D1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

Settings can be pretty liberal. The only reason i'd print in lower layer height is to have the holes printed as strong as possible, especially if you only have 8mm screws.

comments.text:
If you wire the switch using the other contact, then no change is required to the stock firmware.
Similar idea with mine http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1936329

title: Dolls House Eames Table and Chairs

description.text:
A set of retro Eames tables and chairs in miniature, for a very special friend.
https://www.instagram.com/nedintheclouds/

The model furniture is roughly 1:12 scale.
This was done to a strict time frame so the designs are still a little rough. The chair seat and table top are printed in Faberdashery's Arctic White, the table and chair legs in Desert Tan.
The chair seat is the most difficult component so I have provided an .stl file with supports already included. The other files should print successfully without any additional supports (although a heated bed for the table top might help).

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

As mentioned, the chair seat has supports already in the file and the others should print successfully without supports. DO NOT be tempted to print at a lower resolution! The miniature detail means 0.2 is the lowest you can go in order to achieve a decent finish.

1. Chair seat - you will need to remove the supports from the chair seat. These have been generated in Meshmixer and should be easy to removed using a pair of pliers.
  2. Chair and Table Legs - these need to be glued to the underside of the table top and chair seats. Leave to fully set before attempting step 3.
  3. Using some black cotton thread and a needle, gently thread and criss-cross thread through the holes in the chair and table legs to imitate the metal bars seen on the original furniture.

description.text:
Mini Mazzer coffee grinder chute to stop all the coffee going everywhere when you flick the doser.

This is a work in progress,
I cut 1cm off the bottom of the funnel so it doesn't drag coffee off the portafilter when you pull the portafilter out.
Todo: Give the left mounting hole more horizontal tolerence - i.e. make it a bit wider (doesn't fit exactly on machine - currently some filing is needed.
Enjoy!

Update

Now remodelled with a larger and better fitting hole that works nicely. (originally I made the hole a bit smaller hoping for a tight fit but PLA has almost no stretch.

Story

Well I needed a handle for an old rasp and Bunnings near me have stopped selling handles, and I didn't want to spend $20 on a new rasp. Then I thought "hang on a second - I can print one!" so I got out the awesome callipers from Jaycar and started modelling in 3D Fusion.

Created in Fusion 360 with a profile sketch and Revolve, fillet. Then made the tool and subtracted it from the handle using Combine.
I have included the Fusion 360 files with target and tool, if you want to properly remix this.

Print variables:

Using Cura
I printed this vertically, with a 18mm radius raft.
Skin: 4 layers
Infill: Triangle pattern 30% is plenty strong enough
High quality is recommended and in my case it took around 12 hours.
You should be able to turn support off if printing vertically from the hole side up.

title: Case for Estes Proto X micro quad

description.text: Simple custom case for for Estes Proto X micro quad. Storage for charge cable and spare blades in the bottom of the box.

I started with the original package and a ruler. I scanned both using a flatbed scanner.
The ruler was used to adjust scaling in software. I then made it a black and white, and cleaned up the edges. In Inkscape i used the option to Trace Bitmap producing a point map and exporting it as a .svg that was imported into 123d design. focused on the Plate and once i was happy with spacing and the quad sat like it was suppose to, i designed the rest of the box around the plate.

title: Customizable HTC Vive Welding Headgear Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This bracket allows you to attach your HTC Vive VR goggles to the Miller Electric 256174 headgear for welding masks.

It is a remix of Thing:1620362 by nw15062. The original model's surfaces didn't quite align for the first layer, resulting in a rough outside appearance once installed. It also seemed a bit short, causing the googles to be closer to your face than necessary.

This remix prints smoothly, was extended by ~1cm and is also customizable, in case you need the googles to be even further away from your face. The attachments points on the headgear allow for adjustment, so make it rather too long than too short. (The original model's length is ~72mm.)

The current default length of 80mm allows me to keep/use the forehead strap.

Notes:

You will probably want to print with supports, although they may be a PITA to remove.

Infill doesn't really matter that much, but i went for 25% to make it sturdy.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
The Dyson V8 I got comes with 5 extra accessories, however only 2 can be fitted in wall mount... And what to do of the rest?
With this print all my accessories now fit on the wall mount!

This is for V8 ONLY.
You will need to print:
DysonV8HolderLeft.stl : The left part, can fit 2 accessories on top and one at the bottom
DysonV8HolderRight.stl : The right part, can fit 1 accessory on top and one at the bottom
DysonV8HolderBottom.stl x2 : part that locks in the board to fit an accessory below the board

Each side clips inside the wall mount and done!

Update 2017-01-12: I have updated the design so that there is a little recess in the twist and lock mechanism for the bottom part so that it will avoid free rotation

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I sliced it with cura 2.3.1 and used 3 solid layers for top and bottom surfaces and 2 shells for walls.
Printed in PLA using 5mm Brim

Carefully remove supports inside the clips.
Once you have removed the supports on the bottom of the board, fit the bottom part and twist to lock.
This piece might require a bit of glue to avoid it rotate and unlock when clipping or unclipping an accessory.

The idea was taken from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1946252 but then I designed it from scratch using FreeCAD.
I can provide the freecad file for people interested.
And if you need another configuration (for instance 2 on left and 3 on right), let me know and I'll see what I can do.

title: Charmander with Pokeballs Toothbrush or Pencil Holder

description.text:
Charmander toothbrush or pencil holder. The hole is around 45mm, to make sure it could take at least 2 brushes. Enjoy!

WARNING: The tail goes lower than the feet ( to reduce the supports needed) so lower his feet to the build platform before slicing, and the extra tail will be lost. I'll fix it if/when I get a chance.

I got my 1st 3d printer for x-mas, and after messing around with trying to get a non-level stock bed to work, I finally got my printer working with a piece of glass to have a flat place to print. That meant it was time to try my hand at 3d drawing/editing for the 1st time in 10 years (and I needed a new toothbrush holder my wife would approve of.) The Pokeballs are hollow to hold things. I still haven't calibrated ANY of the other settings, so my supports were getting knocked, and I had to play tricks to make sure the bridging worked. You can probably print MUCH faster than I did with a properly working printer, but I let this run for about 2.5 days to make sure it was right!

Printer:

Sunhokey Prusa I3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed this starting at 40mm/s with 200c nozzle and 60c bed, and slowed down to a 50% feed rate and 190c nozzle and 55c bed before getting up to his right hand, which needed bridging. I resumed the speed when the bridging was complete.

This was sliced with Cura, and the supports were over the build plate only. Honestly, it really only needed support under the arms, nose and chin. Cura WAY over-supported where it didn't need it, and made a mess.
Because of the supports, this will need some cutting and smoothing. I sliced with Cura, and the pictures shows NO post processing other than pulling off their supports.

description.text: This is a 2-D model of Chicken Little. We chose to do Chicken Little because as a child that was one of my favorite movies. Convenient enough, it was one of her favorite movies as well, so we decided to do Chicken Little.

Project 3: 2D Art
Problem Statement: With a partner, you will design a “2D” placard using Solidworks. You and your partner will have the same design which meets the constraints below, and you will EACH use Solidworks to create your design.
Constraints: Should have a flat back; detail will be on the front side
Should fit inside a box that is 10 cm x 10 cm when lying flat
Should be no more than 1 cm thick
Should be as detailed as possible
Detail will be made using sketches that are extruded to different heights
No error messages
Do not extrude contours - each feature should have its own sketch
Part should be CENTERED about the origin
Demonstrate efficient use of construction lines
Demonstrate efficient use of automatic and manual relations
Demonstrate efficient use of Smart Dimensions
Demonstrate efficient use of mirroring
Demonstrate efficient use of linear or circular patterns

This is a Work In Progress drivetrain parts kit.

Compatible with some OpenRC parts, this will sure help 'drive' your projects a step forward ;)

More parts will come, including gearboxes, differentials, transfer cases and MORE!


U-Joint

Simple assembly, using 1.75mm filament push-fitted through the joint and melted at the end. The included design is not currently ment for usage, just testing. You may 'remix' the design to fit your needs.

Remix of the "Reach 3D Z Axis Upper Brace" by jdvarmit.

Made the z-brace so it attaches to the vertical 2040 with M5 bolts and t-nuts.
Also added M3x40 screws and nuts, with springs, so you can adjust how far out it sits from the 2040. This way it has some give, but will stabilize your z-screw.

This mod MIGHT help with z-wobble, and it DOES make the printer more quiet!

Hardware needed:
1 608-2RS bearing
2 pcs. M5x10
2 pcs. M5 t-nuts
2 pcs. M3x40
2 pcs. M3 nuts
2 springs (10-15mm minimum length)

description.text:
This is a simple 18650 charge pack I made.
I had bought some boost usb modules which turned out to be pretty rubbish at charging my phone. I had some buck converter (step down) modules that could take the higher voltage of two 18650 batteries and bring it down to 5v for usb. THIS IS A HACK!, There is nothing stopping the voltage in the batteries from going below its recommended amount.

There's a space between the cells to fit your electronics. I used copper tape (slug tape) to make the contacts either side of the batteries and soldered my wires to them. My one can't charge the batteries but if you find a good boost converter (step up module) and a lipo charger you can wire the batteries in parallel and make a powerbank. I have to remove my batteries and charge them separately in a 18650 charger.

The case parts are done as 0 infill and if it finishes with a sealed top you would need to cut it off with a stanley knife. I did it on low resolution and it looks fine.

Because there is a symmetry on the bottom case i utilised this to make a switch mechanism. Using an off centred bit of copper tape inside the bottom case it would make a circuit only on one rotation.

Also, although it might be a little messy, I found that a heated craft knife can be used to cut a hole for the usb port. BE CAREFUL!

I am not responsible for any injury or damage to your devices ect. You do everything at your own risk, and make sure you are confident in the skills required before attempting to make this.

print_settings.Notes:: Print settings probably don't matter, but it depends on the STL model you are using. Just make sure larger molds stick to the bed well (enough brim etc).

description.text:
Open Multi-Mold Generator

A mold generator for multiple side-by-side open molds with either positive or negative inset. Generates an object with multiple molds in a grid enclosed by walls and a configurable seperator between them.

Two example models that show the possibilities of the generator are included in the files section.

Features include:

  • Load a custom STL model
  • Switch between negative or positive molds with a single flag change
  • Configure mold dimensions and wall/base thickness
  • Freely choose the number of side-by-side molds in the final object
  • Choose between full walls, a small seperator or nothing at all between the sub-molds
  • Optionally completely customize the seperator shape between the sub-molds

This generator also doubles as a conventional mold generator by simply setting the number of molds to 1x1.

I use this for making soap that is later cut into seperate parts. Another idea is to use this for chocolate bars but I've yet to try this.

RepRap Kossel

Print settings probably don't matter, but it depends on the STL model you are using. Just make sure larger molds stick to the bed well (enough brim etc).

description.text:
Da Vinci had a great engineering mind that the people who lived with him at one time, might not appreciate. Most inventions of Da Vinci it was impossible to realize with the help of tools XV - XVI centuries. All technical genius idea remained only on paper - in pictures, the drawings and detailed description. Only five centuries later, people who read the manuscript, tried to embody the idea of Da Vinci to life by designing mechanisms for his drawings.

I set myself the task to design a part of the machinery with the ability to reproduce their home. Not only repeating appearance. But all the moving parts.

If you like, you can support this project! https://igg.me/at/DaVinciMachines

comments.author: CaravanMad

comments.text:
Hi CaravanMad,
I built the boxes in 3mm MDF, not 4mm. Also, any other kind of laser cutable material in 3mm should work, like plywood, HDF or acrylic. Probably easiest to try one of those first.
As for adjusting, the easiest way to go about it is to just scale everything up or down. So if you want to use 6mm MDF, just scale everything up to 200%, and you should be good to go. This of course increases the size of your boxes, but it's still easier than adjusting the original. I hope that works for you.

title: Camera Mount Holder for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
This is how I mount my Raspberry Pi Camera v2.1 to the Y axis and heated bed carriage of my Prusa i3 MK2. My way to keep an Octoprint eye on your print.

The lower bracket is placed along the front beam of the headed bed holder of the i3 MK2.

This does not contain the camera case itself. I used the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:92208 Raspi Camera case and added a M3 screw for mounting. This can be seen in the images. I suggest using a shorter M3 screw, to get the camera close to the bed.

In the current configuration it is not easy to adjust the camera viewpoint. If this becomes an issue I will try to find a better mounting solution. I am open to suggestions.

Things to keep in mind:

  1. Make sure to print in ABS or other more heat resistent material, since it is very close to the heated bed.

  2. The display does not longer fit in the front of the printer when this mount is installed. Make sure to test the full range of movement after you attach your camera.

Have fun and
docreatethings

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used ABS since it is very close to the heated bed, see the note above.

The camera clip was printed with a brim since I had trouble getting it to stick to the bed.

For the lower bracket I enabled supports in Slic3r.

As for Infill: I do not think it makes a huge difference, but since it is moving rapidly with the print bed i wanted some stiffness of the part. Depending on the weight of your camera it might make sense to increase the infill even a little above 30%
The M3 screws are currently quite a tight fit. The camera case screw is a self locking nut to keep it in place during printing-

title: OmniCamera
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An omnidirectional camera using a cheap Christmas ball ornament as a reflector.
I used thin struts rather than an clear tube to hold up the reflector because I was having glare issues with glass tubes.  glass that isn't meant to be optical doesn't have anti-reflective coatings.  The trade-off with the struts is that things will get dirty, and the view is slightly occluded.
This is a camera for my future telepresense  robot.  I plan to use it on an autonomous powerwheels sooner than that.

github might have a more up-to-date .scad file. https://github.com/markfinn/markbot/tree/master/omnicamera This allows 360 degree viewing from one webcam. I used a Logitech HD C510. Print the plastic pieces, cut some metal struts from sheet steel or extruded aluminum, add the insides of a webcam. add a little square of glass, lots of epoxy and screws, then mount it on a pvc pipe. I hope to start printing one tonight. You can export a .dxf for the metal (and glass) to help get the idea where to cut, but Openscad will also print the calculated strut length, you entered the width, and the cutout is non-precision.

title: A Slightly Postmodern Shelf
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
January 3

This is a remix of my "Very Modern" Shelf. With this remix, I opted for a corrugated exterior for the shelf, in order to reduce both material and warpage. Since I wanted to print in ABS, the solid-walled original design was a problem. To speed up slicing, the exterior component STL is modeled as a solid. Simply print with 0% infill and 0 solid layers at the top. The interior bracket should be printed with a relatively heavy infill.

The shelf bracket mounts to the wall with two or three screws, and the exterior piece slides over top. I sized this to be pretty small, so that it is less likely to be overloaded. Perfect for a small tablet and some reading glasses.

Update: I included a new version of the Grasshopper file that provides separate control for corrugations on the vertical and horizontal surfaces ("Shelf 3.gh"). Along with the new source file, I've included two new generated STLs (the "shelf 7" files). These files produce wider and shallower shelf.
Pictured on the shelf are the Smithsonian female blue crab, loubie's Aria the Dragon, CreativeTools' 3DBenchy, 3DHubs' Marvin, and my own Parametric Stand.

Also included is the Rhino + Grasshopper source files, which can be used to make a shelf of any size.

This is for Pittsburgh's Fun a Day, 2017.

title: Stereographic projection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model is featured in figure 3.12 of Visualizing Mathematics with 3D Printing. Video.
Stereographic projection is a map from the sphere to the plane: Imagine straight lines going from the north pole of the sphere down onto the plane. Each line hits the sphere in one point and the plane in one point. Stereographic projection maps that point on the sphere to the point on the plane.
If you put a light source at the north pole of this sculpture, the rays of light effectively do stereographic projection! The curves on the sphere cast shadows, mapping them to a straight line grid on the plane.
Stereographic projection is also available at Shapeways. Update: added a version of the file with a wider base for easier printing.

comments.text: Hi, How did you make this, mathematically that is.
comments.author: IcanCwhatUsay

comments.text: Mathematically, this is the inverse stereographic projection of the square grid to the sphere. To design it, I drew the square grid, coned it to the north pole of the sphere, then used the intersection of that cone surface with the sphere to cut out windows in the sphere. There is also a little more messing around beveling to make sure that none of the edges of the model are too sharp.

comments.text: I don't have a heated bed... but on the back top near the gears I found a 5. And by broke off I meant the extruder caught the piece and it came off the print bed.
That happens on my printrbot jr sometimes. try adjusting infill, supports, and scale. Sometimes adjusting the z offset might help.
comments.author: Makeaholic

comments.text: I have a Printrbot Jr V2 as well - ="thingiverse-e8493eb7b5ef1095328dc3186bb20c4e:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/thingiverse-e8493eb7b5ef1095328dc3186bb20c4e/Shantorian3d what settings have you found to work? I've tried adjusting just about everything I can think of.

I haven't printed this design yet, but with designs similar to this, i find the trick is to adjust the z-offset to make sure the bottom sticks well. If the base is too small, make sure you have supports enabled in slic3r. A tip for the z-offset, adjust manually. Make sure the extruder is cool, first. Then place a normal sheet of (2d) printer paper under the extruder. Then home on the Z axis. if it is positioned well, you should be able to pull the paper out with only a slight resistance.

author: 3DFazz

description.text:
The shoes hold a phone with a 4" screen quite easily but for larger phones you make wish to enlarge it to fit. The texture of the printing looks very much in keeping with a fabric covered shoe.
The original shoe file was loaded into Meshmixer and chopped up and reassembled to leave the shoe with a cutout for the phone to stand in. The original shoe was large, maybe full size so this was resized to be 75mm high. Back in Meshmixer the shoe was then mirrored to make a matching pair and two shoe moved to slightly overlap near the toes.
This was loaded into Cura to make ready for printing in PLA with a layer height of 0.2mm and 60% fill. A Brim was used in Cura to stabilise the printing on the table, particularly for the heel as this part is a high thin print until it joins the rest of the shoe. You may wish to add supports to the high heel to stabilise it more during the printing.
Mk3 Version
The only problem I've had with printing is the alignment of the tall heel to the body of the shoe when the two get to meet up. I've added support to lock the heel to the instep around half way up and this solves the problem. Still printed at 75mm high on a brim at 0.2mm and 60% fill.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

A brim was added rather than a raft for printing
I have added support between the heel and the shoe and haven't found a need for any more although you may need to add supports for a larger print.

remixed_from.title: Brigintine New Jersey Outdoor Sailboat Sculpture

title: Decorative outlet cover with seagulls and sailboat

description.text: A decorative electrical outlet cover for your sea themed rooms. I printed it with supports since it has space behind the boat

comments.text: I printed this, the hole for the outlet seems correct, but the distance between the center of the two outlets seems to be off.  Anyone else experience any difficulty printing and making this fit?
comments.author: Lightning_rod88

comments.text: A great idea of combining elements to form the exact model you want.  This is the benefit of 3D printing.
comments.author: paulsroom

comments.text: I was thinking of printing some seagull plaques to go with the decor.  I love the seagull design!  I think it has a serene feeling to it.
comments.author: paulsroom
